An example: You build your building in a minute. Then you upgrade it in an hour. Then you upgrade it in I think three or six hours. Then in 24 hours. And that is only if you have enough people.
Wait, what? Yes, you need free people to upgrade buildings. Which you get - surprise - by building and upgrading certain buildings. If you have partial people, the upgrade takes longer.

reviewText:
TL;DR : Nice Concept, Poor Execution. No Sound, Microtransactions. Quite fun to play as a break. 7/10

FULL REVIEW.

This game is interesting to say the least, but somewhat lacking in it's delivery.

Let's start with me turning the game on, quick download, quick start up, Simple graphics, but not terrible. However, no sound.
I first thought it was a bug or something but after checking a few times, this game dosent have sound files. At all.

This game looks and sort of plays like a Facebook game, but it is more easily compared to Travian, in which you create homes, on a hexagonal area, build up resources and expand to different areas. At time of writing i have only played about an hour.

The game is ported from a mobile game (as clear in some text documents) but they have changed the interface to make it more PC gamer friendly, and I commend them for that. A nice simple tutorial quest system that goes on for about 20 minutes before you were considered to be in charge of what you were doing, which is nice.

The combat system is good at a glance, simple RTS but on a longer timescale. Creating troops and having them fight on a different area. It reminds me of the Total War series, but backwards. You manage a city and what buildings appear, but then have a larger map view to move armies around a hexagonal area. These hexagons have different boosts to different units and make an intresting combat system.

Like all facebook games it seems plagued with micro-transactions. Which in my opinion are not an issue. They are not predominant on the screen and you have to go through several clicking to speed up a process. It's there, but not directly advertised. Besides, a free to play game has to make money somehow.

As I sit here waiting for my population to rise so I can build more buildings to gather more resources, I am pulled in by a strange charm to this game. It feels a bit like alot of other games, but has a much better combat and fighting system. I can only reccommend you at least try this game, just to see if it intrests you.

reviewText: This game makes a nice break to the day and doesn't require heavy micromanagement. You might find yourself staying up scouring the internet for strategies and guides, and each one leaves you with multitudes of ways to achieve your goals, but not all of the ways will be best for your race, hero, and play style.  The best thing I enjoy though is the hero system.  Each hero class is unique and customizable at higher levels.  The NPC monster ruins that pop up provide an addicting hunt and kill component, and if you are good enough, eventually you will find and conquer ruins with monster bosses which can reward you with hoards of loot.

reviewText:
Though I am a fan of this genre I was disappointed with My Lands. A large part of this is simply because My Lands doesn't belong on steam where its effectively tied to a single computer. You need the ability to connect from a browser and your mobile devices, but according to a post from the Devs in the google play store the steam version is on a different server so it cannot be accessed vie the web or mobile devices.

This could have been mitigated if it had a better queuing system, but you need to pay Black Gems to get any sort of queues, and there is no building queue. You start with a small number of Black Gems and they can be earned within the game by destroying ruins and harvesting the proper locations, but unless you are really patient there simply aren't enough of them without paying money. Since the game is already free on the web, I would preferred to have the steam version cost money but include the premium benefits and share the same servers as the browser version.

My other complaints are that everything takes longer in My Lands than in similar games and the interface could use some improvements. This type of game relies on an active player base but the build time ramps up so quickly that new players don't have time to get hooked. As for the interface there is no sound, scouting is instant but the information isn't saved anywhere, and you can't see at a glance where you explored or attacked or even who is a legal target.

The game DOES have potential and I may continue playing the browser version. The different races are interesting, you have a high level of control over your city, the tutorial quests are helpful and most importantly it is entirely up to you when you open yourself to PVP. These are all strong benefits but are outweighed by the flaws. This is not a bad game, its just a bad _steam_ game. While you can successfully take a browser game and put it on steam, you need to make sizable changes for it to succeed.

The game requires the use of Black Gems that require money to purchase.

There is achievements and rewards for completing 150 quests + in a row without failure. These quests were to unlock a weekly boost in certain categories. I can only assume the quest will come back after a week if I did purchase the service. The science track lets you research new things. One of these is the ability to get a hero. It is researchable 3 times and you can get up to 3 heroes. Only after you research rank one do you see the painful black gems appear as a requirement for rank 2.

While you can estimate 1,000 black gems to cost 15$, you cannot purchase in blocks of 1,000 gems. You must purchase 650 gems (10$) or 1500 gems (20$). This essentially means that in order to get a second hero you must pay 20$. I do not wish to even know what rank 3 will charge you.

reviewText:
This review is about my experience with My Lands: Black Gem Hunting. I spent many hours on this game so I could tell you just about everything about it but I will shorten it to how I feel about the game overall.

First off, I do not like RTS games at all. I had played a few online browser and app RTS games in the past such as Travian, Combat Grounds, and Game of War (btw do not ever play GoW). They were fun sometimes but got old after awhile and once you start to become powerful you always get shot down by higher ranked people in clans/guilds who paid thousands of real world money to get to their level. I have also played the Stronghold series and do not enjoy those games. My Lands was sort of an exception to my experience with RTS games.

I started playing this game because I got a free 6 month premium account and figured, why not give it a try? Plus I read you can make money playing the game. Sweet! In the beginning, I really did not know what I was doing but I thought it was kinda fun. The more I started to play and learn about the game, I realised just how much strategy and meticulous, critical planning the game requires. This discovery made the game more intriguing and enjoyable. Once I found an English speaking clan (lots of Russians play, i.e. the majority) I was set. I was a free to play player for a long time and I had NO issues with being F2P. I  was mostly PvE on the Age of Abundance server but I was PvP on occasion, and more so on the other server. Of course if I was super rich the game would be easier, but I learned through reading the My Lands encyclopedia, forums, and from my clan members how to gain power and defend myself from all attacks.

The only con I can say about this game is that it requires you to be on every single day. I would say no less than 2-3 separate times EACH day. It is an RTS after all.
If you miss a day several things can happen:
1. You get attacked
2. You miss a monster ruin (which are crucial to gaining resources and power)
3. You lose an auction
4. Your clan needed your help but you were afk
5. Your mine gets stolen
6. If it's your 7th or 14th consecutive missed day (can't remember which) your city gates open, people leave your villages (no resources gathered), then they leave your cities.
7. If you are gone a month your account(s) is/are deleted.

I was loyal to this game and determined to make money playing it. I was on everyday for months having fun every time I played. That is why my hours are so high. Most of it was not idling. Unfortunately, the place where I was staying had terrible internet which would not allow me to access Steam 90% of the time. I missed some weeks and got attacked but I was still strong in the game and my clan supported me. Basically, it could have been worse... Now I've quit My Lands indefinitely because I just logged on and both of my accounts are gone.

If you like RTS games, My Lands is fun. The graphics are nice. The UI is not hard to figure out. The devs added some fitting music after a few months. You can make money playing it by turning black gems collected into money. I believe it's 100 gems = $1.00. Apparently players have made over $2.5million playing the game. It takes a lot of time if you are F2P though. I earned $0.00 in my 650+ hours...

I recommend it if you have the time.
